transcript:
Patient: I am a bit nervous about ending therapy. I've made a lot of progress, but I worry about maintaining it on my own.

Therapist: It's completely normal to feel nervous about this transition, Emilio. You've been doing great work, and it's understandable to have some concerns about what comes next. That's why we're going to spend some time today creating a relapse prevention plan. This will include identifying early warning signs that you might be slipping back into old patterns, as well as strategies for getting back on track.

Patient: That sounds really helpful. I want to make sure I have a solid plan in place for after our sessions end.

Therapist: Absolutely. We'll work together to create a comprehensive plan that feels manageable and sustainable for you. One important aspect of relapse prevention is recognizing the early signs that your depression symptoms might be returning. What do you think some of those signs might be for you, based on your experiences?

Patient: I think one early sign for me is when I start isolating myself and avoiding social interactions. I also tend to have more negative thoughts and self-criticism when I'm starting to feel depressed again.

Therapist: Those are great insights, Emilio. Avoidance and increased negative self-talk can definitely be early indicators of a potential depressive episode. What are some other signs you've noticed in the past?

Patient: I also tend to have trouble sleeping, either sleeping too much or not enough. And I lose interest in things I usually enjoy, like cooking or singing.

Therapist: Sleep disturbances and loss of interest in pleasurable activities are common symptoms of depression. It's good that you're able to recognize these patterns in yourself. As part of your relapse prevention plan, we'll identify specific action steps you can take if you notice these early warning signs.

Patient: That makes sense. What kind of action steps do you think would be helpful?

Therapist: One important step is reaching out for support, whether that's talking to a trusted friend or family member, attending a support group, or even scheduling a booster session with a therapist. It's also crucial to prioritize self-care during these times, even if you don't feel motivated to do so. This might include sticking to a consistent sleep schedule, engaging in physical activity, or practicing relaxation techniques like deep breathing or mindfulness.

Patient: I can see how those things would be helpful. It's just hard to motivate myself to do them when I'm feeling down.

Therapist: That's a valid point, Emilio. When we're feeling depressed, it can be challenging to engage in self-care activities, even though we know they're beneficial. That's where having a solid plan in place can be helpful. We can create a list of specific, concrete actions you can take when you're noticing early warning signs, so you don't have to rely on motivation alone.

Patient: That sounds good. I think having a clear plan would make it easier to take action, even if I don't feel like it.

Therapist: Exactly. We can also include some coping statements or affirmations in your plan, to help challenge the negative thoughts that might be holding you back. For example, you could remind yourself, "I know from experience that going for a walk usually helps me feel a bit better, even if I don't feel like doing it in the moment."

Patient: I like that idea. It's helpful to have those reminders when I'm struggling.

Therapist: Another important aspect of relapse prevention is ongoing self-monitoring. This might involve tracking your mood, sleep patterns, and engagement in self-care activities, so you can catch any potential issues early on. We can create a simple tracking system that works for you, whether that's using a mood tracking app, keeping a journal, or even just rating your mood on a scale of 1-10 each day.

Patient: I think journaling could be helpful for me. I've always found writing to be a good outlet.

Therapist: Journaling can be a great way to process your emotions and keep track of your mental health. We can brainstorm some specific prompts or questions you can use to guide your journaling practice, if that would be helpful.

Patient: Yeah, I think that would be good. Sometimes I stare at a blank page and don't know where to start.

Therapist: That's a common challenge with journaling. Having some structure or prompts can make it feel more manageable. We can also include journaling as part of your relapse prevention plan, with specific questions related to monitoring your mood and identifying early warning signs.

Patient: That sounds like a good plan. I'm feeling a bit more confident about managing my depression after therapy ends.

Therapist: I'm glad to hear that, Emilio. Remember, having a relapse prevention plan doesn't mean you'll never struggle with depression again. It's normal to have ups and downs, and there might be times when you need additional support. The goal is to have a clear roadmap for how to manage those challenges when they arise.

Patient: That makes sense. I know it won't always be easy, but I feel like I have more tools to handle it now.

Therapist: You've made incredible progress over the course of our sessions together, Emilio. You've developed a wide range of coping skills and strategies, and you've demonstrated a strong commitment to your mental health. I have full confidence in your ability to continue this work independently, and to reach out for support when needed.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I really appreciate all your help and guidance throughout this process.
